Award.AwardTitle: Modeling Bubbly Flows and Bubble-Mediated Gas Transfer in High Wind Conditions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bubbles in the ocean are a key component of air-sea gas transfer at moderate to extreme wind speeds. They enhance gas transfer rate by providing a pathway in addition to the ocean surface. Due to surface tension and hydrostatic pressure exerted on bubbles, gases are able to dissolve at supersaturated conditions. The surface ocean is, therefore, supersaturated with outgassing at the ocean surface and interior dissolution through bubbles. The primary objectives of this study are to better understand processes governing the evolution of bubbles and dissolved gases under high winds and to improve parameterization for bubble-mediated gas flux. Three hypotheses, identified based on previous observational and theoretical studies, will be tested: (1) Gas dissolution through bubbles is important in determining mixed layer dissolved gas concentration under a hurricane; (2) Wind speed dependence for bubble penetration and bubble-mediated gas flux is smaller in high wind conditions; (3) Bubble-enhanced effective solubility for Dimethyl Sulfide and the kinetics of the carbonate system have substantial impacts on air-sea flux of these gases. The hypotheses will be tested using a coupled - large eddy simulation - bubble population - dissolved gas concentration model, which has been shown to faithfully reproduce the simultaneous evolution of and the interplay among oceanic surface boundary layer turbulence, bubbles of multiple sizes with multiple gas components, and the dissolved concentrations of multiple gases. The model also includes the bubble-induced enhancement in effective solubility for polar gas DMS and chemical reactions for the carbonate system. The model will be forced by realistic wind and wave conditions under hurricane Frances (2004), where high quality oceanic measurements of turbulence, dissolved oxygen and Nitrogen will be used to gauge the model realism, as well as steady winds.

Intellectual Merit :
Subsurface bubbles, especially in high wind conditions, are hitherto insufficiently understood, and the contributions of bubbles to the total air-sea gas flux are poorly constrained and have not yet been included in any existing climate simulations or biogeochemical process estimates. The synthesis of simulations and data will provide accurate description of processes governing bubbles and dissolved gases at high spatial and temporal resolutions. Results of this study will provide fundamental understanding of and mechanistically based parameterization for bubble distribution and bubble-mediated gas transfer. They will also be applicable to the air-sea transfer of other reactive and non-reactive gases.

Broader Impacts :
The research in bubbles and air-sea gas transfer in high wind conditions contributes broadly to the understanding of the earth system in terms of both the physical coupling of the ocean and atmosphere and the global biogeochemical cycling. Better parameterization of bubble-mediated gas flux for large scale and climate models will result in significant improvements in the modeling and budget estimate of climatically and environmentally important soluble gases including carbon dioxide, oxygen and Dimethyl Sulfide. This study will improve our capability to predict future environmental and climatic changes, and will provide better scientific basis for decision makers in politics and industry on a range of issues such as climate and energy. It, therefore, has important economic and societal implications. Although this study focuses on the impact of bubbles on air-sea gas transfer, better description of subsurface bubble fields also leads to better characterization of sound and light propagation at the surface ocean and benefits the ocean engineering community. The project will support a new investigator. Besides publishing in refereed journals, the PI will actively participate in conferences and workshops organized by established scientific groups and societies and will develop collaboration with other colleagues in the air-sea gas exchange community. Scientific results will also be presented to the general public on the PI's website. Project materials will be incorporated into the University of Washington's continual outreach effort to local schools, museums and community groups. The PI and Co-PIs will continue to be involved in outreach activities through the Seattle science festival and other volunteer activities at local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gas bubbles, visually identified as whitecaps at the ocean surface, are ubiquitous in the upper ocean. When ocean surface waves break, gas bubbles of a range of sizes are generated. Gas bubbles have a natural tendency to rise because of their density is negligible compared to that of seawater, while the turbulent ocean currents attempt to suspend them. While in the water, gas bubbles exchange gases with ambient water, contributing to the exchange of gases between the ocean and the atmosphere.

 

The primary objective of the project is to investigate the effect of gas bubbles on the air-sea transfer of environmentally and climatically important gases such as O2 and CO2. Bubbles have two effects on air-sea gas transfer: First, they provide a venue for gas transfer in addition to the air-sea interface, leading to a faster air-sea gas transfer rate. Secondly, they drive the ocean to supersaturation since surface tension and hydrostatic pressure squeeze gases from bubbles into the water even when the ocean is slightly supersaturated. The primary tool for the project is a high fidelity computer model that simulates the concurrent evolution of turbulent ocean currents, gas bubbles, and dissolved gases.

 

Synthesizing computer simulations and measurements at Ocean Station Papa in the subpolar Pacific Ocean, we demonstrated that gas bubbles are critical for the accurate modeling of the mixed-layer concentration and saturation anomalies of dissolved O2 and N2. While wind speed has long been used as the primary parameter to calculate air-sea gas flux, we showed that sea state, a measure of how developed the wave is with respect to the wind, is also important when the wind is rapidly changing. Sea state controls the distribution of gas bubbles and gas flux through bubbles by determining the amount and depth of gas bubbles generated under breaking waves and by modulating the intensity of turbulence that suspends gas bubbles. During a period in late fall of 2011 when a winter storm passed the studied location, gas fluxes through bubbles when the wind strengthens can be more than twice as large as those when the wind weakens.

 

In a subsequent study, we examined the effect of gas bubbles on air-sea CO2 flux under Hurricane Frances (2004). Hurricanes are thought to play a significant role in the low-latitude ocean CO2 efflux because of the strong wind. Using conventional gas flux formulas without the bubble-induced supersaturation, a number of studies have shown that air-sea CO2 efflux contributes to 10% to 30% of CO2 efflux. By synthesizing measurements taken using autonomous observing platform called Lagrangian floats and computer simulations, we showed that CO2 efflux including the effect of gas bubbles is only about 10% of that estimated using traditional air-sea gas flux formula.

 

In addition to studying gas bubbles and their effect on air-sea gas transfer, we investigated the evolution of generic buoyant particles representing some of the important aquatic pollutants such as spilled oil and ocean plastics. While the vertical distribution of buoyant particles are relative well studied, the horizontal spreading (dispersion) of those particles by upper ocean turbulent currents has never been studied. Using the computer model, we demonstrated that the horizontal spreading of weakly buoyant particles is controlled by the vertical shear of horizontal mean current while that of strongly buoyant particles is dominated by the horizontal velocity fluctuations. We also developed a formula for the horizontal spreading of buoyant particles that could be used in operational models for spilled oil and ocean plastics.

 

Finally, we also revisited the effect of the earth’s rotation on upper ocean turbulent currents that drive gas bubbles and other buoyant particles. Except right at the equator, the earth’s rotation has an upward component and a northward component. The effect of the upward component, famously known as Coriolis Effect, is well understood while that of the northward component is relatively less explored. We found that upper ocean turbulence and vertical mixing change with wind directions when the northward rotation is considered, and the dependence on wind direction varies with geographic locations, water column density structures, and wave conditions.

 

The project has partially supported one master student and one doctoral student at Louisiana State University (LSU). Both students successfully defended their thesis and dissertation, respectively. During the course of the project, the PI developed new lectures on ocean modelling and marine pollutants for a general education (GE) class offered to undergraduate students of non-STEM students at LSU. The PI also developed research projects for students at a local middle school and gave lectures on ocean modelling in a summer camp offered to middle and high school students.
